articles.author: Lee Meyer
articles.description:
My thesis for today's article offers further reassurance that inline conditionals are probably not the harbinger of the end of civilization: I reckon we can achieve the same functionality right now with style queries, which are gaining pretty good browser support.
The What If Machine: Bringing the “Iffy” Future of CSS into the Present originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: The What If Machine: Bringing the “Iffy” Future of CSS into the Present

articles.author: Ryan Trimble
articles.description:
A while back on CSS-Tricks, we shared several ways to draw hearts, and the response was dreamy. Now, to show my love, I wanted to do something personal, something crafty, something with a mild amount of effort.
Handwriting an SVG Heart, With Our Hearts originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Handwriting an SVG Heart, With Our Hearts

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Adam’s such a mad scientist with CSS. He’s been putting together a series of “notebooks” that make it easy for him to demo code. He’s got one for gradient text, one for a comparison slider, another for accordions…
Scroll Driven Animations Notebook originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Scroll Driven Animations Notebook

articles.author: Juan Diego Rodríguez
articles.description:
We’ve been able to get the length of the viewport in CSS since… checks notes… 2013! Surprisingly, that was more than a decade ago. Getting the viewport width is as easy these days as easy as writing 100vw, but …
Typecasting and Viewport Transitions in CSS With tan(atan2()) originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Typecasting and Viewport Transitions in CSS With tan(atan2())

articles.author: Ryan Trimble
articles.description:
I enjoy organizing code and find cascade layers a fantastic way to organize code explicitly as the cascade looks at it. The neat part is, that as much as it helps with "top-level" organization, cascade layers can be nested, which allows us to author more precise styles based on the cascade and inheritance.
Organizing Design System Component Patterns With CSS Cascade Layers originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Organizing Design System Component Patterns With CSS Cascade Layers

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Stationery Pad is a handy way to nix a step in your workflow if you regularly use document templates on your Mac. The long-standing Finder feature essentially tells a file’s parent application to open a copy of it by default, ensuring that the original file remains unedited.
Make Any File a Template Using This Hidden macOS Tool originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Make Any File a Template Using This Hidden macOS Tool

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
A little gem from Kevin Powell's "HTML & CSS Tip of the Week" website, reminding us that using container queries opens up container query units for sizing things based on the size of the queried container.
Container query units: cqi and cqb originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Container query units: cqi and cqb

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
The steps for how I took the Baseline Status web component and made it into a WordPress block that can be used on any page of post.
Baseline Status in a WordPress Block originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Baseline Status in a WordPress Block

articles.author: Ryan Trimble
articles.description:
Are partials the only thing keeping you writing CSS in Sass? With a little configuration, it's possible to compile partial CSS files without a Sass dependency. Ryan Trimble has the details.
Compiling CSS With Vite and Lightning CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Compiling CSS With Vite and Lightning CSS

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Did you see the release notes for Chrome 133? It's currently in beta, but the Chrome team has been publishing a slew of new articles with pretty incredible demos that are tough to ignore. I figured I'd round those up in one place.
Chrome 133 Goodies originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Chrome 133 Goodies

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
When using View Transitions you’ll notice the page becomes unresponsive to clicks while a View Transition is running. […] This happens because of the ::view-transition pseudo element – the one that contains all animated snapshots – gets overlayed on top 
…
Keeping the page interactive while a View Transition is running originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Keeping the page interactive while a View Transition is running

articles.author: Juan Diego Rodríguez
articles.description:
All of the things that the CSS Working Group would change if they had a time-traveling Delorean to go back and do things over.
The Mistakes of CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: The Mistakes of CSS

articles.author: Juan Diego Rodríguez
articles.description:
The @view-transition at-rule has two descriptions. One is the commonly used navigation descriptor. The second is types, the lesser-known of the two, and one that probably envies how much attention navigation gets. But read on to learn why we need types and how it opens up new possibilities for custom view transitions when navigating between pages.
What on Earth is the `types` Descriptor in View Transitions? originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: What on Earth is the `types` Descriptor in View Transitions?

articles.author: Andy Clarke
articles.description:
After 20 years since Andy Clarke first published his book about Multi-Column Layout in CSS, he's back to encourage a fresh look at CSS columns for enhanced readability and design flexibility.
Revisiting CSS Multi-Column Layout originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Revisiting CSS Multi-Column Layout

articles.author: Preethi
articles.description:
When it comes to positioning elements on a page, including text, there are many ways to go about it in CSS — the literal position property with corresponding inset-* properties, translate, margin, anchor() (limited browser support at the moment), and so forth. The offset property is another one that belongs in that list.
Positioning Text Around Elements With CSS Offset originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Positioning Text Around Elements With CSS Offset

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eric Burel)
articles.description: The OWASP vulnerabilities list is the perfect starting point for web developers looking to strengthen their security expertise. Let’s discover how these vulnerabilities materialize in full-stack web applications and how to prevent them.
articles.title: How OWASP Helps You Secure Your Full-Stack Web Applications

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: The goal of content design is to reduce confusion and improve clarity. Yet often it’s difficult to pinpoint a problem as user feedback tends to be not specific enough. But: we can use a few simple techniques to assess how users understand and perceive content. Let’s take a look. Part of [How To Measure UX & Design Impact](https://measure-ux.com/) by yours truly.
articles.title: How To Test And Measure Content In UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Matt Zeunert)
articles.description: Optimizing web performance means looking beyond surface-level metrics. Time to First Byte (TTFB) is crucial, but improving it requires more than tweaking server response time. Matt Zeunert breaks down what TTFB is, what causes its poor score, and why reducing server response time alone isn’t enough for optimization and often won’t be the most impactful change you can make to your website.
articles.title: Time To First Byte: Beyond Server Response Time

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Tomasz Jakut)
articles.description: Tomasz Jakut reflects on the evolution of web design, from the days of table-based layouts and Flash games to the rise of responsive web design (RWD), which often feels like the end of history in web layout. But as 2025 marks the 15th anniversary of Ethan Marcotte’s article, it’s worth asking whether something significant happened after RWD — something so seamless that it went almost unnoticed.
articles.title: Taking RWD To The Extreme

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Edoardo Dusi)
articles.description: In today’s web development landscape, the concept of a monolithic application has become increasingly rare. Modern applications are composed of multiple specialized services, each of which handles specific aspects of functionality. This shift didn’t happen overnight - it’s the result of decades of evolution in how we think about and implement data transfer between systems. Let’s explore this journey and see how it shapes modern architectures, particularly in the context of headless CMS solutions.
articles.title: Integrations: From Simple Data Transfer To Modern Composable Architectures

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s make the most of the shortest of all months, with a new collection of desktop wallpapers celebrating new opportunities, sweet memories, happy little moments, and everything in between. All of them created with love by the community for the community. Enjoy!
articles.title: Look Closer, Inspiration Lies Everywhere (February 2025 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Design systems play a crucial role in today’s digital landscape, providing a blueprint for consistent and user-friendly interfaces. But there’s another tool that deserves equal attention: the digital playbook.
articles.title: The Digital Playbook: A Crucial Counterpart To Your Design System

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Brecht De Ruyte)
articles.description: It’s not always the big features that make our everyday lives easier; sometimes, it’s those ease-of-life features that truly enhance our projects. In this article, Brecht De Ruyte highlights two such features: `@starting-style` and `transition-behavior` — two properties that are absolutely welcome additions to your everyday work with CSS animations.
articles.title: Transitioning Top-Layer Entries And The Display Property In CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick O’Brien)
articles.description: After months of anticipation, debate, and even a bit of apprehension, Svelte 5 arrived earlier this year. Frederick O’Brien caught up with its creator, Rich Harris, to talk about the path that brought him and his team here and what lies ahead.
articles.title: Svelte 5 And The Future Of Frameworks: A Chat With Rich Harris

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alvaro Saburido)
articles.description: Alvaro Saburido delves into the current state and challenges of Open-Source authoring, sharing lessons learned from both community- and company-driven initiatives.
articles.title: Navigating The Challenges Of Modern Open-Source Authoring: Lessons Learned

sources.title: freeCodeCamp Programming Tutorials: Python, JavaScript, Git & More

articles.description: When writing unit tests in .NET, you may need to verify that methods are logging exceptions, errors, or other key information. You might think, No problem, I'll just mock ILogger using my favourite mocking library – for example Moq, NSubstitute, or F...
articles.title: How to Use FakeLogger to Make Testing Easier In .Net

articles.author: Ijeoma Igboagu
articles.description: Building an authentication system can be complex, often requiring a server to store user data. Sometimes, you need a faster, easier solution. For those new to development or without technical expertise, managing servers, databases, and user logins ca...

articles.description: On this week's episode of the podcast, I interview Julia Undeutsch who is a self-taught software engineer and accessibility specialist. She works at a big European company making software more accessible for people with disabilities. Julia taught her...
articles.title: She taught herself coding at age 30 for zero dollars [Podcast #160]

articles.author: Alex Tray
articles.description: These days, cyberattacks are growing concerns that everyone on a development team should be aware of. This means that if you’re a developer, you should learn some basic cybersecurity skills. After all, cyber attackers are typically developers themsel...
articles.title: Why Cybersecurity Skills Are Important for Front-End Developers

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: Building interactive and accessible web applications is a crucial skill for modern developers. React, one of the most popular JavaScript libraries, provides a powerful way to create dynamic user interfaces. A great way to deepen your understanding of...
articles.title: Build a Memory Game in React

articles.description: Understanding fundamental programming concepts is crucial for success in computer science, especially for students preparing for the Cambridge A-Level Computer Science exam. Mastering these topics not only helps in exams but also builds a strong foun...
articles.title: Learn A-Level Computer Science Concepts

articles.author: Orim Dominic Adah
articles.description: I recently migrated some tests from Jest to the Node.js test runner in two of my projects that use MongoDB. In one of those projects, test runtime was reduced from 107 seconds to 25 seconds (screenshot below). In the other project, test runtime was r...
articles.title: How to Write Tests Using the Node.js Test Runner and mongodb-memory-server
